title: Eduard Franz
text:
Eduard Franz Schmidt (October 31, 1902 – February 10, 1983) was an American actor of theatre, film and television. Franz portrayed King <a href="Ahab">Ahab</a> in the 1953 biblical <a href="low-budget%20film">low-budget film</a> "<a href="Sins%20of%20Jezebel">Sins of Jezebel</a>", <a href="Jethro%20%28Bible%29">Jethro</a> in <a href="Cecil%20B.%20DeMille">Cecil B. DeMille</a>'s "<a href="The%20Ten%20Commandments%20%281956%20film%29">The Ten Commandments</a>" (1956), and Jehoam in <a href="Henry%20Koster">Henry Koster</a>'s "<a href="The%20Story%20of%20Ruth">The Story of Ruth</a>" (1960).
Life and career.
Franz was born in <a href="Milwaukee%2C%20Wisconsin">Milwaukee, Wisconsin</a>. His childhood ambition was to become a commercial artist, a goal that led him to enroll later at the <a href="University%20of%20Wisconsin%E2%80%93Madison">University of Wisconsin</a>, where he joined the Wisconsin Players Theater, a new student group. Performing in the theater's 1922-1923 season reignited his ambition to become an artist, although one of a different type, an actor. A year later, he was cast in Chicago productions of the Coffee-Miller Players. Dropping his surname, Franz next acted with the Provincetown Players in New York's Greenwich Village, a hothouse of theatrical ferment that had first brought the world the dramatic works of writers <a href="Eugene%20O%27Neill">Eugene O'Neill</a>, <a href="Susan%20Glaspell">Susan Glaspell</a>, and <a href="Edna%20St.%20Vincent%20Millay">Edna St. Vincent Millay</a>. Franz also appeared with <a href="Paul%20Robeson">Paul Robeson</a> in "<a href="The%20Emperor%20Jones">The Emperor Jones</a>" and with Walter Huston in "<a href="Desire%20Under%20the%20Elms">Desire Under the Elms</a>". He continued to perform until his stage work was interrupted by the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a>.
By then married to his wife Margaret, he tried to eke out a living as chicken farmers in Texas. The young couple soon returned to Wisconsin, where Franz acted in regional theater while teaching art to pay the bills. By 1936, he was a player on the national stage, performing from coast to coast. He became a leading Broadway actor for nearly 30 years, in such plays as "First Stop to Heaven", "<a href="Home%20of%20the%20Brave%20%28play%29">Home of the Brave</a>", "Embezzled Heaven", and "Conversation at Midnight". He made his film debut in a bit part, in 1947, in "<a href="Killer%20at%20Large%20%281947%20film%29">Killer at Large</a>", but followed that brief appearance the next year with a memorable role in the motion picture "The Scar" (also titled "<a href="Hollow%20Triumph">Hollow Triumph</a>"). His fourth movie saw him acting with <a href="John%20Wayne">John Wayne</a> in "<a href="Wake%20of%20the%20Red%20Witch">Wake of the Red Witch</a>", in 1948. He portrayed Chief Broken Hand in "<a href="White%20Feather%20%281955%20film%29">White Feather</a>". He played such intellectuals as Dr. Stern in "<a href="The%20Thing%20from%20Another%20World">The Thing from Another World</a>" (1951), a university professor in "<a href="The%20Four%20Skulls%20of%20Jonathan%20Drake">The Four Skulls of Jonathan Drake</a>" (1959), and Justice <a href="Louis%20Brandeis">Louis Brandeis</a> in "<a href="The%20Magnificent%20Yankee%20%281950%20film%29">The Magnificent Yankee</a>" (1950), a role he reprised in the 1965 television adaptation. He appeared in a 1957 television <a href="Beyond%20This%20Place%20%281957%29">adaptation</a> of <a href="A.%20J.%20Cronin">A. J. Cronin</a>'s novel "<a href="Beyond%20This%20Place">Beyond This Place</a>", which was directed by <a href="Sidney%20Lumet">Sidney Lumet</a>.
Franz performed as well in two separate <a href="remake">remake</a>s of <a href="Al%20Jolson">Al Jolson</a>'s 1927 cinema classic "<a href="The%20Jazz%20Singer">The Jazz Singer</a>", each time playing the key role of the aged and ailing synagogue <a href="cantor">cantor</a> upset by his son's decision to pursue a secular show-business career rather than continue the family tradition and follow in his father's religious footsteps. Those remakes were the <a href="The%20Jazz%20Singer%20%281952%20film%29">1952 film version</a> of the story starring <a href="Danny%20Thomas">Danny Thomas</a> and the <a href="The%20Jazz%20Singer%20%281959%20film%29">1959 television version</a> starring <a href="Jerry%20Lewis">Jerry Lewis</a>.
In 1956, Franz appeared on a first-season episode of "<a href="Gunsmoke">Gunsmoke</a>" titled "Indian Scout", performing in the role of Amos Cartwight, a scout for the United States cavalry who knowingly leads the troopers into an ambush by a <a href="Comanche">Comanche</a> war party. That same year he guest-starred with <a href="Joan%20Fontaine">Joan Fontaine</a> in the episode "The De Santre Story" of the <a href="NBC">NBC</a> <a href="anthology%20series">anthology series</a> "<a href="The%20Joseph%20Cotten%20Show">The Joseph Cotten Show</a>". Later, In 1958, Franz was cast in the second season of "<a href="Zorro%20%281957%20TV%20series%29">Zorro</a>", playing the role of Señor Gregorio Verdugo. He guest-starred as Jules Silberg in the 1960 episode "The Test" of <a href="Columbia%20Broadcasting%20System">CBS</a>'s anthology series "<a href="The%20DuPont%20Show%20with%20June%20Allyson">The DuPont Show with June Allyson</a>".
In 1961, Franz starred in the episode "The Duke of Texas" of <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> series "<a href="Have%20Gun%20-%20Will%20Travel">Have Gun - Will Travel</a>." Also, in that same year, Franz guest-starred as Gustave Helmer in the <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> legal drama "<a href="The%20Law%20and%20Mr.%20Jones">The Law and Mr. Jones</a>" with <a href="James%20Whitmore">James Whitmore</a> in the title role and <a href="Jack%20Mullaney">Jack Mullaney</a> as a second guest star. About that same time, he portrayed characters on NBC's anthology series "<a href="The%20Barbara%20Stanwyck%20Show">The Barbara Stanwyck Show</a>" and on the NBC western "<a href="Cimarron%20City%20%28TV%20series%29">Cimarron City</a>". Always dedicated to the theater, despite his television work, Franz in 1961 performed in the world premiere in Los Angeles of Edna St. Vincent Millay's poetic drama "Conversation at Midnight", co-starring with <a href="James%20Coburn">James Coburn</a> and <a href="Jack%20Albertson">Jack Albertson</a>. Two years later, Franz was cast as psychiatric clinic director Dr. Edward Raymer in 30 episodes of the weekly ABC medical drama "<a href="Breaking%20Point%20%281963%20TV%20series%29">Breaking Point</a>" with co-star <a href="Paul%20Richards%20%28actor%29">Paul Richards</a>. Then, in 1964, he reprised his role in "Conversation at Midnight" at <a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a>'s <a href="Billy%20Rose">Billy Rose</a> Theatre. Both that stage version of Millay's work and the one done in 1961 were produced by <a href="Worley%20Thorne">Worley Thorne</a> in association with Susan Davis.
